abstracts.cdata!:
Ratings for the E-Development Project
            for Ukraine were as follows: the Bank performance was
            unsatisfactory, and the Borrower performance was highly
            unsatisfactory. The project was initiated in late 2001 and
            approved by the Board on May 6, 2003. The loan and project
            agreements were signed on October 1, 2003, and became
            effective on July 26, 2004. Long delays in signing and
            ratification of the Loan and critical interruptions in the
            procurement process in late 2004/early 2005 were mostly
            related to political reasons and not to the loan itself. In
            the hindsight, these delays led to losing momentum in
            project implementation. Some of the lessons learned from the
            project are: 1) support of key high-ranking officials may be
            enough for project approval but is insufficient for
            implementation and the sustainability of outcomes,
            particular in countries with institutional challenges, such
            as Ukraine; 2) a fully functioning and staffed PIU and
            remunerated for their services is essential for effective
            and efficient project implementation. The Project
            Implementation Unit (PIU) was not fully staffed and in some
            cases the salaries of the staff were not paid for over a
            year, although allocations were made under the Loan for
            these payments; and 3) the Project Appraisal Document (PAD)
            states that the first year's procurement documents were
            ready, but it took almost till March 2005 till the first
            Terms of Reference (TORs) were prepared and ready for
            tender. The TORs for the first year's procurement
            activities should have been prepared and agreed prior to
            Board approval. In addition, the Bank should have ensured
            that the agreed procurement methods are the most appropriate
            for the type of procurement envisaged under the project.

repnme.cdata!: World Bank projects in private sector development

abstracts.cdata!:
Ukraine's European course, declared
            by the supreme state power and supported by society,
            determines the nature of market reforms carried out by the
            Ukrainian Government. This line of reforms is actively
            supported by the World Bank, with its most important
            projects aimed at building up the private sector in Ukraine.
            In 1996 and 1998, the enterprise development adjustment
            loans (EDAL) I and II were implemented in two stages. In
            2002, the World Bank approved granting a loan to Ukraine for
            the private sector development project. This project is a
            systemic (adjustment) type, being oriented not only to the
            extensive development of private enterprises, but also to
            increasing the efficiency and profitability of production,
            and the manufacture of competitive products. The project
            objective is also to ensure that privatized enterprises
            themselves, after acquiring know-how and work experience
            under the conditions of new economic realities, become
            experts and leaders of enterprise restructuring, supporters,
            and implementers of market ideas in the regions.
            Introduction of the latest models of information and
            communication technologies (ICT) can considerably increase
            the efficiency and expeditiousness of decisions approval,
            stimulate the development of the private sector, and
            strengthen civil society in Ukraine. In order to attain
            these goals, a credit agreement on financing the project
            Ukraine: e-development was signed in 2003 between the World
            Bank and the Ukrainian Government. The activities envisaged
            by the project have positive prospects for consolidating
            administrative reform.

abstracts.cdata!:
This report presents World Bank financed
            projects under preparation namely, statistical system
            modernization project; Ukraine e-development project; rural
            land titling and cadastre development project; rural finance
            project; social assistance reform administration project;
            equal access to quality education reform project; municipal
            development loan; and Crimea coastal zone management and
            nutrient reduction project (global environmental facility
            (GEF) black sea and Danube strategic partnership program).

5086438.majtheme: Public sector governance,Social dev/gender/inclusion,Financial and private sector development

abstracts.cdata!:
The development objective of the
            E-Development Project for the Ukraine is to enhance
            efficiency of the Government's decision-making process
            for public procureement and documentation flow, foster
            private sector development, and strengthen civil society
            through introducing innovative models of Information and
            Communication Technologies (ICT) solutions. There are three
            project components. The E-Government component provides for
            development and introduction of the public E-Procurement and
            E-Documentation flow models aimed at increasing efficiency
            and transparency of the Government actions. amendments
            required to facilitate introduction of the Internet-based
            transactions in the procurement cycle, and carrying out a
            pilot testing in one of the Borrower's state agencies
            with larger volume of the procurement transactions.
            Fine-tuning of the developed model will be based on the
            feedbacks and recommendations from public agencies and
            vendors to assure its replicability. The E-Documentation
            flow subcomponent will develop the most appropriate model
            for documentation flow to increase efficiency of the
            decision-making processes (preparation, appraisal, approval,
            implementation, supervision and completion phases) of the
            document flow for issuing and monitoring the resolutions and
            orders of the Borrower's Cabinet of Ministers, extended
            pilot testing thereof, and introduction of a workflow
            information system to allow the secure processing and
            exchange of e-documents. The second component, the
            E-Business Environment component, will assess the main
            bottlenecks in current legislation that hamper e-business
            growth. Legislative, normative and regulatory environment
            adequate to accelerate enabling on-line transactions will be
            developed. It will also provide framework for their
            introduction and secure a favorable e-business regulatory
            environment for the other Parts of the Project, thereby
            complementing them. The third component, the Public-Private
            E-Dialogue component, will provide for on-line tools for an
            exchange of ideas between public authorities and
            representatives of private sector and civil society at the
            national and regional levels. Introduction of these tools
            would i) improve public sector transparency, and ii)
            strengthen the role and involvement of civil society in the
            governance process.
